comments.commentBody: Signor Ugarte was Jewish.  Stuff happens.

There are plenty of reprints and new editions of these classics (I saw some Enright reprints a few months ago with cute contemporary cover art). It might be galling to have to buy the same book over again, but I'd think it worth it to get them to read it.

My favorites for this list (on top of almost all the previous suggestions, and KJ's) are Caddie Woodlawn, Understood Betsy, and, if you can find it, the Magician's Apprentice trilogy by Tom McGowen.

If every corporation has a religion and the right to impose the tenets of its particular faith on its employees, then as Justice Scalia suggested, religious exemptions will render the law unenforcible. As the Christian Science faith founded by Mary Baker Eddy, recognizes prayer as the only acceptable form of medical treatment, a Christian Scientist employer could then invoke religious objections to providing any form of medical insurance, whatsoever, to his employees.

Now, imagine the impact of a Hobby Lobby court victory on the reporters and other employees of the Christian Science Monitor, assuming that the newspaper is wholly owned by the Church. Would the newspaper be able to assert the tenets of its faith to obtain exemption from providing healthcare under the ObamaCare employer mandate? Would employees be fired for obtaining medical care, even when solely at their own expense?

Given the tendency for mass social engineering to distort the economy, I would suggest that many full time jobs would be reduced to part time and that if Hobby Lobby prevails, there will be mass conversions of employers to Christian Science. But the only thing that I can say with any certainty is that if my parents had been Christian Scientists, I would not be here posting this comment. And for that fact, I truly thank the Lord!

From my own experience I have discovered that there are other and more valid means of achieving honor and integrity than through the prestige of your position.  The people I respect the most are honorable because they are focused on the honor that is based on respect for others and themselves.  Many of them have had difficult struggles in their lives.  They judge themselves, as well as others, with compassion.  You are right when you say that we have limited control of our destinies. But the real honor and integrity comes when you can live within that destiny and be compassionate and true to yourself and others.  If you recognize that your feeling of helplessness is "learned" helplessness, then you are approaching a place where you can learn to negotiate this part of your life in a different way, and find the other paths to honor and integrity that are available to you.  They are there, and I hope that you find them.
Are you kidding?  It's called buying food & making rent. You're either company material, or pretend to be—simple as that.

I loved this video. Someone living life on their own terms. That takes so much courage.

As a hospice nurse, I have seen so many people die, never having really been allowed, for whatever reason, to be their own true self.

This is what we should listen to and follow; our own true voice. When is the last time you heard it?

It seems there are two principal themes running through American society today--continuous expansion of gun rights and the cementing of the power of corporations (through the legal artifice of personhood) and the moneyed elite (through the thoroughly ridiculous equating of speech with money). Should these trends continue, one can envision a day when the only alternative available to ordinary Americans to preserve what little property and political power they are left with is via the barrel of a gun, presumably aimed at corporate leaders and the rich, whilst claiming "stand your ground" rights under an argument that the shooters feared for their lives and safety.

Of course, this is ridiculous. But so is this ruling. And so is this Court, which is in the tank for the Republican Party--from its ruling in Bush v. Gore to the present day. Justice Roberts' legacy is the complete politicization of the Supreme Court and a total squandering of the Court's formerly respected position as an impartial arbiter of the law in American society.

I want to live in your world. In my world, many aren't paying close attention to the issues of the day. The Koch Brothers wouldn't be throwing their money around if they didn't feel they were getting a return. To equate one presidential win (2012) with the fact that the GOP retained the house through gerrymandering despite gaining 1.4 million fewer votes isn't reflective of the big picture. Here in CO, we are being subjected to millions of dollars of advertising against ACA being spent by people from outside the state. Isn't my freedom of speech lessened when someone else is aloud to drown it out in a sea of misleading, blatantly non-factual advertising?

No shock or surprise. The rich won in 2000 and have reaped the rewards of the lavish political spending ever since. The prescient nature of the editorial boards column on Rep. Ryan's budget talking points yesterday was merely a prelude to today's judicial blasphemy. The court is where the real power to subvert the will of the majority lies. How different would it be if Harriet Miers' nomination had gone through?

America moves toward a permanent peasant class, where wealth has free speech and Ryan/Rand's underclass is muted with no voice. People naively voted for this foolishness and some for Ralph Nader in there false equivalence then and reinforce it now. History will not look fondly on these judicial puppets with their belief that money trumps people's rights and the common man or woman are nothing in the constitution.

All is not lost. There is hope that intelligence brings people out to vote for Representatives that will be humble servants of the people and craft legislation to fix our democracy by returning *we the people* to power. Don't hold your breath. Use it to talk to people, everybody, and let them know to vote for people who are responsible not to money but to the people.

with all this money now floating around legally, the media are going to be hard pressed to political news because there won;'t be any more corruption cases--it's now legal to buy a politician. what's the world coming to?
It'll also provide the side benefit of being a place to launder all that drug money and income that corporations sneak in trying to not pay taxes on.
People like Jack Abramoff will be out of jobs because now politicians can be bought in plain sight--no more messy envelopes in the washroom or the lounge at the Paris Hilton . Yes indeed, politics will now be in the open for all to see. Sad that most folks won't understand what's going on.
Ralph Nader's book was about the Corvair model.  The other mid-sixties GM cars were good. Chevy Chevelle, Buick Special/Skylark, Pontiac Lemans, etc.  Very nice!

That first paragraph hits it out of the park.  The Old GM is well documented in Unsafe At Any Speed by Ralph Nader, published in 1966(!). The same calculation that the death toll settlements are cheaper than changing a  defective part is documented in meeting transcripts.   Today's hearing made clear that the Old GM is still alive, and that many people are dead as a result.
Put the facts on the table. If the GOPers claim that Dubya and Cheney are being smeared, this report will either prove or disprove that. So out with the report ASAP.

Apparently, none of this is going to matter. GM's financial bankruptcy wiped out the company's liability for any malfeasance or misfeasance that took place prior to that event.

Of course, there is the matter of the company's moral bankruptcy. And how its board conveniently pushed a woman forward to take on the attacks on the company for decisions she had no part in and no knowledge of until two weeks after her appointment.

I used to play flute in the pit orchestra for community theater productions of musicals. They ranged from godawful to decent, but were always fun.

During a rehearsal for "Man of La Mancha," the director has us begin at measure 53 of one number. The score (musical scores are all hand-written and full of errors) had every fifth measure numbered. When we began, it sounded absolutely horrible -- even worse than we normally sounded.

It turned out that there were only four measures between 50 and 55. Some people counted back from 55 to get to 53 and some counted forward from 50, resulting in different measures.

I was the first to spot the problem and, in lusty voice, sang out, "Bar 54, Where Are You?"

Happily the demographics were mostly aligned with it, but you still probably had to be there.

While many are agreeing that America is not where it once was, it is important to recognize that the "good old days" were not necessarily all that grand. Our social progress hasn't always been up to par and there is a deeper interest rooted in financial/economic well-being while as stated, the most important factors of society itself/the population are disregarded.
It may be fair to reason that all these issues that are now under a microscope have always been around. We have recently been propelled into a more cyber-centered world and have many more outlets to get our voices heard. While this technology based system has hindered us in ways, it has also opened doors to bring light to issues such as Americas ranking not being where we feel it should be. While we point fingers and blame society, it's important to remember that we are society. We are what drives the big industries and the media. We are fuel to the fire and the energy exerted in blaming and moping can in fact be used in educating and in progressive movements.

On this day the rich officially took over the American political system.  Not that much will change, they are already running the show. So those of us left out of the system have one or two options and these may well be the ruby slippers: make decisions about who we elect based on facts and always follow the money.

Sarah.

Many Americans would be inclined to side with you, feeling your concerns; your immediate needs for your health care coverage, and the Obama help, for you to be under your parents coverage for a few years.

You site looking forward to its progress in the next years. Surely you must be aligned with the millions of other American college students who want and demand honesty from their elected politicians in Washington.

Yours is the generation that will define which way our country will go; leaning heavily on Washington to subsidize our existence, or be free to follow your dreams and ambitions that many young people do have.

There is more in the life that you face, than a few years of a subsidized health plan you have with your parents. It would be wise to look past this health care debate and see the positive choices you have in your young life.

Good luck to you and your peers.
The West Coast of the Americas is trying to tell us something, no?

Social and economic mobility is probably a good indicator of how well a country is doing in allowing people to define their own life outcome by their own efforts. Unfortunately, we are falling behind in that regard, and it is getting worse. Defining that as a problem is not anti American so much as it is a desire to find some way to improve. We are not no.1, but we should be.

This is old news. '' Lack of access to information is a red flag'' is totally incorrect since internet isn't the heart of information at all. News Papers,Books and TV have been the heart of information for decades and even now if we keep our eyes and ears wide open and willing to grab whatever knowledge available at our disposal including our parents and good old grand parents.

Computer shouldn't be thrust right from childhood. Computer is also called '' GIGO(Garbage in is Garbage out). Traditional method of teaching surely helps. Calculators shouldn't be permitted in primary and middle schools.

The Government must make all education affordable including adult literacy programmes at whatever cost. Old age pensions should be such that pensioners should have some comforts at least in old age after decades of struggle for survival.

Healthcare at basic cost should be provided.

America went from being a culture of meritocracy, of folks being proud of their independence to a culture of narcissism and rationalization.

We applaud success, even when wrongfully achieved! Unfortunately, it takes a long time to change- for the majority livability will continue to exacerbate.

I am struck by how often college coaches suspend star players for unspecified "rules" violations. I've always sensed this is a power trip, more about the coach's authority than the player's (undisclosed) infraction.

This seems like a typical college coach move. Except Jackson is a professional athletes who, unlike a college player, can find employment elsewhere.

Cutting Jackson and getting nothing in return seems, above all else, stupid.

William Rhoden is guessing at the reason(s).  It was reported that the Eagles would release Jackson at least a week prior to the release if they could not trade him.  The Riley Cooper comparison is off base.  It may have been a one time rant.  Jackson campaigned about his contract after the game.  there have been continuous all be it not major issues for I vs. team concepts with Jackson.  No player or recent former player had his back with the release.  Dopey opinion jumping to race related conclusions.

The far right has achieved another milestone in it's quest for legalizing corruption.

They love to say . . . "no laws were broken".

You can do that when you get rid of the laws.

How does Washington's signing of Jackson so quickly, "prove" the Redskins had no concerns? In fact, his talents probably did trump real concerns they would have. Any team signing him would have some concerns. This writer has an agenda, and shapes the facts to fit it. It feels like cheap talk radio, and not worthy of the NYTimes and its readers.

Warren Buffett once famously said: ‘There’s class warfare, all right, but it’s my class, the rich class, that’s making war, and we’re winning.’

Five of nine members of the Supreme Court just nailed the final nail in the coffin.

Real democracy has been a cruel joke for decades. It is now a sham democracy. A government run by plutocrats.
